docs.lead_paragraph: Over the years, any number of coincidental findings have suggested that exposure to a particular substance may cause a certain illness. But under the critical eye of careful research, most of these apparent associations turn out to have no cause-and-effect relationship. The suspicion that vaccines given to infants and children can cause autism is one such association, with attention directed at the vaccines that use the preservative thimerosal, which contains mercury.

headline.main: Vaccines and Autism, Beyond the Fear Factors

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column outlines facts and fears surrounding rise in autism and potential connection to childhood vaccinations containing mercury; cites several studies that disprove connection and National Academy of Sciences panel, which concludes there is not enough evidence to prove or disprove effects of mercury containing preservative thimerosal on children; occurrence of autism has risen from 1 in 2,000 children in 1970 to 1 in 500 today; mercury poisoning effects are assessed and compared to autism; cartoon (M)
docs.snippet: Over the years, any number of coincidental findings have suggested that exposure to a particular substance may cause a certain illness. But under the critical eye of careful research, most of these apparent associations turn out to have no...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since Viagra hit the market five years ago this spring and immediately became one of the best-selling prescription drugs ever, sex researchers have been searching for a treatment that will work as well for women. But something that was obvious to begin with -- that sex mechanics for women are different from those for men -- has proved to be a bigger obstacle than scientists expected.

headline.main: Effort to Make Sex Drug for Women Challenges Experts

docs.abstract: Success of Viagra as treatment for male sexual disfunction has spawned similiar hopes for drug to help women conquer problems with sexual arousal; scientific community has found, however, that female sexual health is more complex than male function and lack of basic physiological knowledge has slowed development of treatment; researchers continue studies to determine mind-body connection, effects of hormones, and physical dynamics of female arousal in hopes of finding corrective therapy; cartoon; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Ever since Viagra hit the market five years ago this spring and immediately became one of the best-selling prescription drugs ever, sex researchers have been searching for a treatment that will work as well for women.    But something that was...

docs.lead_paragraph: Like most doctors, I hear the word ''natural'' a dozen times a day. People ask for a ''natural'' treatment for their insomnia, constipation or sinusitis. They discuss the ''natural'' vitamin-based remedy they have found on their own. They stop a prescription medication because it isn't ''natural'' and head for any of a variety of herbal cures instead. These natural alternatives are not always inexpensive: profiteers lurk in that arena just like any other. Vitamins are made with exactly the same sophisticated chemical techniques as any drug. Herbs are not always gentle, effective or safe, as the recent spate of ephedra-associated deaths shows.

headline.main: In Medicine, Nature Plays Dirty Tricks

docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger Cases article asserts that natural medicines are not necessarily best treatments for illness and that disease by definition is naturally occurring abnornality; gives example of diabetic who refused traditional medicines and experienced first hand nature's ugly side; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Like most doctors, I hear the word ''natural'' a dozen times a day. People ask for a ''natural'' treatment for their insomnia, constipation or sinusitis. They discuss the ''natural'' vitamin-based remedy they have found on their own. They stop a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Smoking and coughing may seem to go together, but it actually takes more to bring on a cough reflex in a smoker than in a nonsmoker, according to a new study. The study, in the current issue of the journal Chest, found that smokers had to inhale almost eight times as much of an irritant before coughing as much as nonsmokers.

headline.main: New Twist on Smoke and Coughs

docs.abstract: Dr Peter V Dicpinigaitis, Albert Einstein College of Medicine Associate Professor, publishes study in journal Chest concluding that cough reflex in smokers requires more stimulus than in non-smokers; possible reasons for this difference are discussed; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Smoking and coughing may seem to go together, but it actually takes more to bring on a cough reflex in a smoker than in a nonsmoker, according to a new study.     The study, in the current issue of the journal Chest, found that smokers had to inhale...

docs.lead_paragraph: In African hospitals, says Dr. Paul D. Blumenthal of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, the cervical cancer wards can be found by smell alone. Women come in when their cancers are bleeding uncontrollably or have eaten into their urethras or intestines. By then, even major surgery will not cure them. They come in to die. But now he and other public health doctors are testing a simple one-visit procedure that could save many of the thousands of women, most in the third world, who die each year of the disease.

headline.main: Procedure May Save Women In Third World From Cancer

docs.abstract: Dr Paul D Blumenthal, of Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, is testing one-visit procedure for women in hopes of reducing cervical cancer deaths, particularly in third-world countries; procedure is described and early on-site research shows positive results with little or no side effects; 80 percent of world's cervical cancer cases are in poor nations and combining diagnosis and treatment into one step avoids problems that can delay or deny care; eventually vaccines could eliminate all cases of cervical cancer; photo (M)
docs.snippet: In African hospitals, says Dr. Paul D. Blumenthal of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine, the cervical cancer wards can be found by smell alone. Women come in when their cancers are bleeding uncontrollably or have eaten into their urethras or...

docs.lead_paragraph: Does pregnancy interfere with concentration and memory? Some pregnant women insist it does. But when their mental abilities are tested, a new study conducted in England says, the answer is no. Dr. Ros A. Crawley of the University of Sunderland, the study's lead author, said the belief that pregnancy brings with it absent-mindedness and other mental lapses is old and widespread.
docs.abstract: University of Sunderland (England) study by Dr Ros A Crawley does not support theory that pregnant women experience decreased mental acuity and shortened memory during pregnancy; surveys given to same women in conjuction with study, however, showed women rated their abilities as altered even when study did not; cartoon (S)
docs.snippet: Does pregnancy interfere with concentration and memory? Some pregnant women insist it does. But when their mental abilities are tested, a new study conducted in England says, the answer is no.    Dr. Ros A. Crawley of the University of Sunderland,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Creatine, an over-the-counter supplement popular with weight lifters, has been used by thousands of people suffering from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., since they learned of a 1999 study involving mice. In it, creatine extended the lives of mice with the disease. Now, a new study, conducted in the Netherlands and published online yesterday by The Archives of Neurology, has found that creatine provides no significant benefit in humans with the disorder, which is also known as Lou Gehrig's disease.
docs.abstract: Utrecht University Dr Geert Jan Groeneveld publishes report in Archives of Neurology citing research that found no significant benefit in creatine therapy for people suffering with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease (S)
docs.snippet: Creatine, an over-the-counter supplement popular with weight lifters, has been used by thousands of people suffering from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, or A.L.S., since they learned of a 1999 study involving mice. In it, creatine extended the lives...

docs.lead_paragraph: Thunderstorms can set off asthma attacks, and fungus may be to blame, a Canadian study has found. In several countries over the years, emergency room visits related to asthma have spiked after severe thunderstorms, the study's lead author, Dr. Robert E. Dales of the University of Ottawa Health Research Institute said.
docs.abstract: Journal Chest publishes University of Ottawa Health Research Institute study by Dr Robert E Dales linking stormy weather with increased incidence of asthma attacks; wind and rain are thought to raise fungus levels in air that, for unknown reason, can intensify asthmatic reaction (S)
docs.snippet: Thunderstorms can set off asthma attacks, and fungus may be to blame, a Canadian study has found.    In several countries over the years, emergency room visits related to asthma have spiked after severe thunderstorms, the study's lead author, Dr....

docs.lead_paragraph: ''Crucial Conversations: Tools for Talking When Stakes Are High,'' by Kerry Patterson, Joseph Grenny, Ron McMillan and Al Switzler, McGraw-Hill, $14.95. How would you like to speak persuasively, not abrasively?

headline.main: A Guide to Talking the Talk

docs.abstract: Authors Kerry Patterson, Joseph Grenny, Ron McMillan and Al Switzler explore verbal communication skills in their book Crucial Conversations: Tools for Talking When Stakes Are High; book takes on conflict discussion and resolution for both personal and business issues, with authors hoping to guide your words toward results; photo (S)
docs.snippet: ''Crucial Conversations: Tools for Talking When Stakes Are High,'' by Kerry Patterson, Joseph Grenny, Ron McMillan and Al Switzler, McGraw-Hill, $14.95.      How would you like to speak persuasively, not abrasively?

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Chronic Pain Solution: The Comprehensive Step-by-Step Guide to Choosing the Best of Alternative and Conventional Medicine,'' by Dr. James N. Dillard with Leigh Ann Hirschman. Bantam Books, $24.95. Pain is no stranger to most of us, but what may be surprising is that the chronic form affects some 50 million Americans and ranks third as a health problem in the United States, behind heart disease and cancer.
docs.abstract: Dr James N Dillard, in his book Chronic Pain Solution: Comprehensive Step-by-Step Guide to Choosing the Best of Alternative and Conventional Medicine, addresses possible treatments for many types of chronic pain; approaches chronic pain, which effects estimated 50 million Americans, with balanced treatment options that combine traditional medicines with alternative therapies; photo (S)
